questions.stem: The nurse performs a medication history on a patient who will begin targeted therapy for cancer with gefitinib. The nurse learns that the patient is taking carbamazepine, a histamine blocker, and warfarin. The nurse will anticipate that the provider will make which change to the medication regimen?
options: Increase the histamine blocker dose.
Decrease the gefitinib dose.
Decrease the warfarin dose.
Increase the carbamazepine dose.
questions.rationale: When patients taking warfarin take gefitinib, the effectiveness of the warfarin is greatly increased, and the bleeding risk increases. Carbamazepine and histamine blockers decrease the effectiveness of gefitinib, so decreasing the gefitinib dose or decreasing the carbamazepine or histamine blocker is not recommended.

questions.stem: A patient who has begun taking nifedipine to treat variant angina has had a recurrent blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg or less. The nurse will anticipate that the provider will do which of the following?
options: Change to a beta blocker.
Add digoxin to the drug regimen.
Switch to diltiazem.
Order serum liver enzymes.
questions.rationale: Hypotension is a common effect of calcium channel blockers and is more common with nifedipine. It is less common with diltiazem, so the provider may order that drug. Adding digoxin, changing to a beta blocker, or ordering serum liver enzymes are not indicated.

questions.stem: A patient with a history of spinal cord injury has severe muscle spasticity. The physician prescribes dantrolene (Dantrium). What should the nurse include in the teaching?
options: We will monitor your liver function periodically, as this medication can affect the liver.
Avoid any movement or exercise while on this drug to prevent injury.
Increase your dose if you don’t feel improvement in a week.
This medication may cause your urine to turn orange; it’s harmless.
questions.rationale: Chronic use of dantrolene carries a risk of hepatotoxicity. Liver enzymes should be monitored, and patients should be informed to watch for signs of liver dysfunction (e.g., jaundice, fatigue). There’s no need to avoid all movement/exercise; in fact, therapy might include exercise for rehab, just carefully. Dantrolene doesn’t typically discolor urine (orange urine is more rifampin or sulfasalazine side effect). Dose changes should be made by the physician; patient should not self-increase as it can be dangerous (especially with liver risk).

questions.stem: A patient who is taking diphenoxylate with atropine to treat diarrhea asks the nurse why it contains atropine. The nurse will explain that atropine is added, in part, to
options: minimize nausea and vomiting.
provide analgesia.
decrease abdominal cramping.
increase intestinal motility.
questions.rationale: Atropine is added to decrease abdominal cramping and slow intestinal motility through its anticholinergic effects. It does not affect nausea and vomiting or pain.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer the first dose of intravenous ceftriaxone to a patient. When reviewing the patient's chart, the nurse notes that the patient previously experienced a rash when taking amoxicillin. What is the nurse's next action?
options: Administer the drug and observe closely for hypersensitivity reactions.
Ask the provider whether a cephalosporin from a different generation may be used.
Notify the provider and suggest an oral cephalosporin.
Contact the provider to report drug hypersensitivity.
questions.rationale: A small percentage of patients who are allergic to penicillin could also be allergic to a cephalosporin product. Patients should be monitored closely after receiving a cephalosporin if they are allergic to penicillin. There is no difference in hypersensitivity potential between different generations or methods of delivery of cephalosporins.

questions.stem: Adenosine (Adenocard) is ordered for a patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). How should the nurse administer this medication?
options: Dilute it in 100 mL and infuse over 30 minutes.
Give it as a rapid IV push followed by a normal saline flush.
Infuse it slowly over 10 minutes to prevent flushing.
Administer it intramuscularly in a large muscle.
questions.rationale: Adenosine has an extremely short half-life (seconds) and must be given as a rapid IV bolus followed by a quick saline flush, usually via a line close to the heart. This ensures it reaches the heart quickly to terminate SVT. Slow infusion or IM administration would not be effective. It is not given as a 30-minute infusion for SVT.

questions.stem: A patient who has major depressive disorder has been taking fluoxetine 20 mg daily for 3 months and reports improved mood, less fatigue, and an increased ability to concentrate. The patient's side effects have diminished with continued use. The only complaint from the patient is regarding the number of medications she takes daily. What will the nurse counsel this patient to discuss with the provider?
options: Discontinuing the medication
Changing to once-weekly dosing
Increasing the dose to 30 mg daily
Decreasing the dose to 10 mg daily
questions.rationale: Once patients have demonstrated control of symptoms with decreased side effects on the maintenance dose of 20 mg daily, patients may be considered for once-weekly dosing. The 20-mg dose is maintenance dosing, so decreasing or increasing the dose is not indicated. Patients should not stop taking the medication abruptly.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving warfarin and notes bruising and petechiae on the patient's extremities. The nurse will request an order for which laboratory test?
options: Vitamin K level
Platelet level
International normalized ratio (INR)
PTT and aPTT
questions.rationale: The INR is the test used most frequently to report prothrombin time results in patients taking warfarin. Warfarin is not an antiplatelet drug, so platelet levels are not indicated. PTT and aPTT are used to monitor heparin therapy. Vitamin K is an antidote for warfarin; levels are not routinely checked.

questions.stem: An older adult with allergies is prescribed diphenhydramine (Benadryl). What should the nurse emphasize during teaching?
options: You can have a glass of wine in the evening while on this medication.
Take this medication on an empty stomach to enhance absorption.
This medication will not cause any cognitive effects.
Do not drive or operate machinery while taking this medication due to possible drowsiness.
questions.rationale: Diphenhydramine causes sedation, and in older adults it can also cause dizziness, confusion, and increase fall risk. They should be cautioned about driving or operating heavy machinery while under its effects. Whether to take with food or not isn’t a major issue (it can be taken with food if stomach upset occurs). It definitely can cause cognitive effects (especially in the elderly, can cause confusion/delirium). Alcohol would potentiate sedation, so they should avoid concurrent alcohol.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a post-operative patient on morphine PCA (Patient-Controlled Analgesia). Which assessment finding is most concerning?
options: Respiratory rate of 8 breaths/minute
Constipation on the second post-op day
Pinpoint pupils
The patient falls asleep easily but arouses to name
questions.rationale: A respiratory rate of 8/min is too low and indicates significant opioid-induced respiratory depression, which is an urgent concern. Pinpoint pupils are an expected effect of opioids (miosis) but not life-threatening by itself. Sedation (falls asleep easily) is an expected side effect as long as the patient can be aroused and respirations are adequate. Constipation is common with opioids and can be managed; it’s not acute. The low respiratory rate is most concerning, possibly requiring intervention like reducing dose or giving naloxone if severe.

questions.stem: A patient who is taking amitriptyline reports constipation and dry mouth. The patient notes that these side effects are a nuisance, but not severe. The nurse will give the patient which instruction?
options: Notify the provider.
Request another antidepressant.
Stop taking the medication immediately.
Increase fluid intake.
questions.rationale: Constipation and dry mouth are common side effects of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), and patients should be taught to manage these symptoms. There is no need to notify the provider or to switch medications unless the side effects become too uncomfortable. Patients should not stop taking TCAs abruptly.

questions.stem: An older patient exhibits a shuffling gait, lack of facial expression, and tremors at rest. The nurse will expect the provider to order which medication for this patient?
options: Carbidopa-levodopa
Rivastigmine
Memantine
Donepezil
questions.rationale: This patient is exhibiting signs of Parkinson's disease and should be treated with a medication indicated to treat Parkinson's disease, such as carbidopa-levodopa. The other drugs are indicated to treat Alzheimer's disease.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about using an ipratropium (Atrovent) inhaler. Which statement by the patient indicates correct understanding?
options: This inhaler will help immediately if I’m having an acute asthma attack.
I might feel jittery and have a fast heartbeat right after using this inhaler.
I should rinse my mouth after using ipratropium to help prevent dryness and irritation.
Ipratropium may cause me to urinate more frequently.
questions.rationale: Rinsing the mouth can help minimize dry mouth and throat irritation from ipratropium. Ipratropium is not a rapid rescue inhaler on its own (onset is a bit slower than albuterol), so it’s often used in combination or for maintenance in COPD. It does not typically cause urinary frequency; if anything, anticholinergic effects could cause urinary retention in sensitive individuals. Tremors and significant tachycardia are more associated with beta-agonists (like albuterol) than with ipratropium.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient how to administer insulin. The patient is thin with very little body fat. The nurse will suggest injecting insulin
options: subcutaneously with the needle at a 45- to 60-degree angle.
in the abdomen only with the needle at a 90-degree angle.
by pinching up the skin and injecting straight down.
using the thigh and buttocks areas exclusively.
questions.rationale: In a thin person with little fatty tissue, the needle is inserted at a 45- to 60-degree angle. In other patients, a 45- to 90-degree angle is acceptable. There is no recommendation for preferring one site over another.

questions.stem: A patient is using a transdermal clonidine (Catapres) patch for hypertension. Which instruction should the nurse include?
options: Apply heating pads over the patch to improve medication absorption.
Remove the patch for a few hours each day to prevent tolerance.
Stop using the patch if your blood pressure is normal for 2 days.
Change the patch every 7 days and apply it to a hairless area on your upper arm or chest.
questions.rationale: Clonidine patches are typically changed weekly and applied to a clean, hairless area on the upper arm or torso. The old patch should be removed before applying a new one. Rebound hypertension can occur if clonidine is stopped abruptly, so continuous use is important until a provider discontinues it. Applying heat can increase drug absorption and risk hypotension, so it should be avoided.

questions.stem: The emergency department nurse is caring for a patient who has received morphine sulfate for severe pain following an injury. The nurse performs a drug history and learns that the patient takes St. John's wort for symptoms of depression. The nurse will observe this patient closely for an increase in which opioid adverse effect?
options: Constipation
Pruritus
Sedation
Respiratory depression
questions.rationale: St. John's wort can increase the sedative effects of opioids. It does not enhance other side effects.

questions.stem: A patient who has Parkinsonism will begin taking carbidopa-levodopa. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: “Call your health care provider immediately if your urine or perspiration turns a dark color.”
“Take the drug with foods high in protein to improve drug delivery.”
“Rise slowly from your bed or your chair to avoid dizziness and falls.”
“Discontinue the drug if you experience insomnia.”
questions.rationale: Carbidopa-levodopa can cause orthostatic hypotension, so patients should be taught to take care when getting out of bed or a chair. Darkening of the urine and perspiration is a harmless side effect. Patients should take the drug with low-protein foods to improve drug transport to the CNS. Carbidopa-levodopa should not be discontinued abruptly because rebound Parkinsonism may occur; insomnia is an expected adverse effect of the drug, and the patient should report this effect to his or her health care provider.

questions.stem: A patient is receiving IV hydromorphone (Dilaudid) for post-op pain. The new nurse asks how hydromorphone compares to morphine. The best response is:
options: They are exactly the same; only the name is different.
Hydromorphone has no side effects, unlike morphine.
Hydromorphone is more potent than morphine, so a smaller dose provides equivalent pain relief.
Hydromorphone lasts much longer, that’s why we use it.
questions.rationale: Hydromorphone is approximately 5-7 times more potent than morphine; thus, lower milligram doses are used to achieve similar analgesia. It is not exactly the same (different drug, different potency). Its duration is similar to morphine (maybe slightly shorter for immediate release forms), not much longer. It has similar opioid side effects (respiratory depression, constipation, etc.) as morphine. So highlighting potency (and thus careful dosing) is key.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about using sublingual nitroglycerin at home. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I may put the tablet in food if I don't like the taste.”
“I may take a sip of water after placing the tablet in my mouth.”
“I will place the tablet under my tongue and let it absorb.”
“I will place the tablet between my cheek and gum.”
questions.rationale: Drugs given sublingually should be placed under the tongue. No foods or fluids should be given, since the tablet must remain under the tongue until it is fully absorbed. Medications ordered to be given “buccally” should be placed between the cheek and gum.

questions.stem: Which statement correctly describes a key difference between succinylcholine (Anectine) and non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium?
options: Succinylcholine has no serious side effects, whereas vecuronium can cause malignant hyperthermia.
Succinylcholine’s effects can be reversed by neostigmine, while vecuronium cannot.
Succinylcholine causes an initial muscle fasciculation (twitch) before paralysis, whereas vecuronium does not.
Patients on succinylcholine remain fully conscious and pain-sensitive, unlike with vecuronium.
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine depolarizes the muscle endplate, causing initial transient muscle fasciculations (twitching) before flaccid paralysis. Non-depolarizing agents like vecuronium simply block receptor without fasciculations. Non-depolarizers can be reversed with cholinesterase inhibitors (neostigmine), whereas succinylcholine’s effect isn’t reversed by neostigmine (it’s actually prolonged by it if given too early). Both types require sedation/analgesia since they cause paralysis without affecting consciousness or pain perception – that’s true for both, not different. Malignant hyperthermia is associated with succinylcholine (and volatile anesthetics), not vecuronium.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving istradefylline for their Parkinson's disease. The patient asks the nurse why this medication was added. The nurse understands that this medication was added to
options: To prevent the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine.
Helps decrease dyskinesias.
To help with tremor.
To reduce “off” periods resulting from long-term treatment with levodopa.
questions.rationale: Istradefylline is an adenosine receptor antagonist used in people with Parkinson's disease to reduce “off” periods in people who have been on long-term carbidopa/levodopa therapy.

questions.stem: Which nursing diagnosis is important to include in the plan of care for a client receiving the angiotensin II receptor antagonist irbesartan (Avapro)?
options: Fluid volume deficit
Risk for infection
Risk for injury
Impaired sleep patterns

questions.stem: A patient with angina is prescribed metoprolol (Lopressor). Before administering the dose, the nurse notes an apical pulse of 52 beats/min. What is the appropriate nursing action?
options: Reduce the dose by half and give it.
Hold the dose and notify the healthcare provider.
Administer the dose and recheck the heart rate in one hour.
Give the dose with atropine to prevent bradycardia.
questions.rationale: Beta-1 selective blockers like metoprolol slow the heart rate. An apical pulse <60 bpm in an adult is generally a reason to hold the beta-blocker and notify the provider. Administering it could worsen bradycardia and hypotension. Adjusting the dose or giving atropine prophylactically is not a standard practice without provider orders.

questions.stem: A young adult female is prescribed metronidazole to treat trichomoniasis. Which of the following is FALSE regarding metronidazole?
options: Metronidazole is available in multiple dosage forms, including oral, topical, intravaginal, and IV products.
Metronidazole is not appropriate for this patient because it is only indicated for bacterial infections.
Metronidazole can be used for both bacterial and protozoal infections.
Alcohol use is contraindicated.
questions.rationale: Metronidazole can be used to treat both bacterial and protozoal infections and would be an appropriate therapy for treating trichomoniasis.

questions.stem: A patient who is intubated develops sinus bradycardia. Which medication will the nurse anticipate administering to treat this symptom?
options: Metoclopramide (Reglan)
Bethanechol chloride (Urecholine)
Atropine sulfate (Atropine)
Benztropine (Cogentin)
questions.rationale: Atropine is most commonly used to decrease salivation and respiratory secretions preoperatively and to treat sinus bradycardia by increasing the heart rate.

questions.stem: Which finding in a patient taking clonidine (Catapres) would warrant immediate intervention?
options: The patient suddenly stopped using clonidine two days ago.
Blood pressure is 150/88 after a week on clonidine.
The patient has lost 2 pounds in the last week.
The patient complains of a dry mouth and drowsiness.
questions.rationale: Abrupt discontinuation of clonidine can cause severe rebound hypertension (dangerous BP spike), agitation, and headache. This situation requires immediate intervention (restarting medication or other measures). A BP of 150/88 after a week might need follow-up but is not an emergency. Dry mouth and drowsiness are common side effects of clonidine (central α2-agonist). Minor weight change is not critical here.

questions.stem: A female patient will receive doxycycline to treat a sexually transmitted infection (STI). What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: The drug is a preferred antibiotic in pregnancy.
Use a back-up method of contraception if taking oral contraceptives.
Nausea and vomiting are uncommon adverse effects.
Increase intake of dairy products with each dose of this medication.
questions.rationale: The desired action of oral contraceptives can be lessened when taken with tetracyclines, so patients taking oral contraceptives should be advised to use a back-up contraception method while taking tetracyclines. Nausea and vomiting are common adverse effects. Doxycycline should not be taken with dairy products. Tetracycline should be used with caution in pregnancy.

questions.stem: A patient receives adenosine (Adenocard) IV for paroxysmal SVT. The patient’s cardiac monitor shows a brief period of asystole after the injection, then normal sinus rhythm. What should the nurse do next?
options: Give the second dose of adenosine.
Continue to monitor – a brief asystole is expected after adenosine.
Begin CPR immediately.
Prepare for immediate defibrillation.
questions.rationale: After rapid IV adenosine, a brief period of asystole or very slow rhythm is common, as the drug transiently blocks AV conduction. This often followed by conversion to normal rhythm, as in this case. The nurse should monitor the patient; no CPR or defibrillation is needed if the patient remains stable and normal rhythm resumes. A second dose is only given if the first dose did not resolve the SVT.

questions.stem: The nurse is assessing the effectiveness of high-dose aspirin therapy for an 88-year-old client with arthritis. The client reports that she can't hear the nurse's questions because her ears are ringing. What action should the nurse implement?
options: Refer the client to an audiologist for evaluation of her hearing.
Advise the client that this is a common side effect of aspirin therapy.
Notify the healthcare provider of this finding immediately.
Ask the client to turn off her hearing aid during the exam.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to give a dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) and learns that the patient takes warfarin. The nurse will request an order for
options: A decreased dose of TMP–SMX.
A different antibiotic.
An increased dose of warfarin.
Coagulation studies.
questions.rationale: Sulfonamides can increase the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. The nurse should request INR levels. An increased dose of warfarin would likely lead to toxicity and to undesirable anticoagulation.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving desmopressin acetate (DDAVP). Which assessments are important while caring for this patient?
options: Urine output and serum sodium
Lung sounds and serum magnesium.
Blood pressure and serum potassium
Heart rate and serum calcium
questions.rationale: Desmopressin is an antidiuretic hormone. The nurse should monitor intake and output as well as serum sodium levels. Side effects and adverse reactions include hyponatremia, cephalgia, dyspepsia, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.stem: A patient who will begin taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) asks the nurse why the combination drug is necessary. The nurse will explain that the combination is used to
options: Broaden the antibacterial spectrum.
Minimize toxic effects.
Produce a synergistic effect.
Improve the taste.
questions.rationale: The combination drug is used to produce a synergistic effect that increases the desired drug response. It does not broaden the spectrum, improve the taste, or decrease toxicity.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has been prescribed azithromycin for an exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. The patient also takes digoxin and warfarin. Which of the following will the nurse expect?
options: Increased effectiveness of digoxin
Decreased effectiveness of warfarin
Decreased effectiveness of digoxin
Increased effectiveness of azithromycin
questions.rationale: Azithromycin can interact with digoxin and warfarin to increase their effects. If azithromycin is added to treat bronchitis, monitoring for increased effects of these medications would be appropriate.

questions.stem: A patient on desmopressin (DDAVP) should be monitored for which electrolyte imbalance?
options: Hyponatremia
Hypomagnesemia
Hypercalcemia
Hyperkalemia
questions.rationale: Desmopressin causes water retention by concentrating urine. If water intake is excessive or dose too high, it can lead to dilutional hyponatremia (low sodium), which can cause confusion, headache, or even seizures. It doesn’t typically affect potassium, calcium, or magnesium directly, but hyponatremia is a well-known risk from water intoxication.

questions.stem: A patient experiences a blood clot in one leg, and the provider has ordered a thrombolytic medication. The patient learns that the medication is expensive and asks the nurse if it is necessary. Which response by the nurse is correct?
options: “You could take aspirin instead of this drug to achieve the same effect.”
“Your body will break down the clot, so the drug is not necessary.”
“The drug will decrease the likelihood of permanent tissue damage.”
“This medication also acts to prevent future blood clots from forming.”
questions.rationale: Thrombolytic medications are given primarily to prevent permanent tissue damage caused by compromised blood flow to the affected area. Thrombolytics do not prevent clots from forming. Aspirin prevents, but does not dissolve, clots. Although the body will break down the clot, the drug is needed to prevent tissue damage due to active ischemia.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer atropine sulfate drops as a mydriatic agent. Which of the following is considered a contraindication to therapy?
options: Bradycardia
Tachycardia
Diarrhea
Constipation
questions.rationale: Atropine sulfate is an anticholinergic medication that is contraindicated in patients with tachycardia and glaucoma. Anticholinergic effects could contribute to worsening constipation, but the presence of constipation would not be considered a contraindication.

questions.stem: A patient who just started using transdermal nitroglycerin reports having headaches. The nurse will counsel the patient to perform which action?
options: Reapply the patch three times daily.
Call 911 when this occurs.
Take acetaminophen as needed.
Notify the provider.
questions.rationale: Headaches are one of the most common side effects of nitroglycerin, but they may become less frequent; acetaminophen is generally recommended for pain. If the headaches do not resolve after continued use, it would be appropriate to discuss alternatives with the provider. The headaches are not an emergency, and the patient does not need to call 911. The patch is applied once daily.

questions.stem: Which patient scenario is most appropriate for a fentanyl (Duragesic) transdermal patch for analgesia?
options: A 70-year-old opioid-naïve patient with sudden severe ankle fracture pain
A 34-year-old with acute postoperative pain 6 hours after surgery
A 19-year-old with intermittent migraine headaches
A 50-year-old with chronic cancer pain who has difficulty swallowing pills
questions.rationale: Fentanyl patches are indicated for chronic, stable opioid requirements (like chronic cancer pain) and in patients who are opioid-tolerant. It provides long-acting pain control but is not suitable for acute or intermittent pain due to its slow onset (it takes ~12-24 hours to reach full effect). For acute post-op or fracture pain in opioid-naïve patients, short-acting opioids are appropriate. A migraine is intermittent acute pain – a patch is not appropriate (they need acute treatment). The 50-year-old with chronic cancer pain is the best fit.

questions.stem: Which morning schedule would indicate to the nurse that the client's teaching has been effective?
options: take medication, go for a30 30-minute morning walk, then eat breakfast
take med, rest in bed for 30 min., eat breakfast, go for morning walk
Take medication with breakfast, then take a 30-minute morning walk
go for a 30-minute morning walk, eat breakfast, then take the med

questions.stem: The healthcare provider prescribes naproxen (Naproxen) twice daily for a client with osteoarthritis of the hands. The client tells the nurse that the drug does not seem to be effective after three weeks. Which is the best response for the nurse to provide?
options: The frequency of the dosing is necessary to increase the effectiveness.
Therapeutic blood levels of this drug are reached in 4 to 6 weeks.
Another type of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug may be indicated.
Systemic corticosteroids are the next drugs of choice for pain relief.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer intramuscular haloperidol to a patient who has schizophrenia. What action will the nurse perform?
options: Use the Z-track method and inject the medication into deep muscle tissue.
Massage the site after injecting the medication to ensure complete absorption.
Use a small-bore needle when injecting the medication.
Teach the patient to return every week to receive medication doses.
questions.rationale: Haloperidol is a viscous liquid and should be injected deep into muscle tissue using a Z-track method. The injection site should not be massaged. Injections of long-term preparations of haloperidol are given every 2 to 4 weeks. Nurses should use a large-bore needle when injecting haloperidol.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving a high dose of intravenous azithromycin to treat an infection. The patient is also taking acetaminophen for pain. The nurse should expect to review which lab values when monitoring for this drug's side effects.
options: Liver enzymes
Urinalysis
Complete blood counts
Electrolytes
questions.rationale: Liver function tests should be monitored in patients taking high doses of macrolides. Because this patient is also taking acetaminophen, the patient may be at increased risk for hepatotoxicity.

questions.stem: When a patient is receiving IV nitroprusside (Nitropress), which precaution is essential?
options: Warm the IV solution to room temperature before infusion.
Maintain the patient supine to avoid headaches.
Cover the IV bag with opaque material to protect it from light.
Infuse the solution with lactated Ringer’s for compatibility.
questions.rationale: Nitroprusside is light-sensitive and must be shielded from light to prevent degradation into toxic byproducts. It should be mixed only with compatible solutions (usually 5% dextrose in water, not lactated Ringer’s). Patient positioning doesn’t prevent nitroprusside-induced headache (a common side effect due to vasodilation). The solution is typically prepared at room temperature; warming is not required beyond that.

questions.stem: When teaching a patient about tamoxifen (Nolvadex), which statement is correct?
options: Tamoxifen can be taken short-term for a few weeks to treat your cancer.
This medication will prevent any menopause-like symptoms.
You should avoid all calcium-rich foods while on tamoxifen.
Tamoxifen may increase your risk of blood clots, so report calf pain or swelling immediately.
questions.rationale: Tamoxifen has estrogen-agonist effects in some tissues, leading to increased risk of thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke). Patients should promptly report symptoms of clots. It actually causes menopause-like symptoms such as hot flashes. It’s usually taken for years (5-10 years) as part of breast cancer treatment/prevention, not just a few weeks. There’s no dietary restriction for calcium; in fact maintaining bone health is important because tamoxifen can help bones, but diet isn’t restricted.

questions.stem: A patient is taking digoxin (Lanoxin) and furosemide (Lasix) for heart failure. This morning the patient’s potassium is 2.9 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate nursing intervention?
options: Administer both medications as scheduled.
Give the digoxin but reduce the dose of furosemide.
Hold the digoxin and notify the provider of the low potassium level.
Offer a potassium-rich snack to the patient and reassess in 4 hours.
questions.rationale: Hypokalemia (K <3.5) greatly increases the risk of digoxin toxicity. The nurse should hold digoxin and notify the provider, as electrolyte abnormalities must be corrected. Furosemide, a potassium-wasting diuretic, likely contributed to this low K; the provider may need to adjust therapy or add potassium supplementation. Simply offering a snack or adjusting doses independently is not sufficient or within nursing scope without an order.

questions.stem: The nurse is educating a patient about glucagon (GlucaGen) emergency use. Which scenario best describes when glucagon should be administered?
options: Inject glucagon into a vein for the fastest action when the patient is awake and shaky.
Use glucagon when blood sugar is high (over 300) to bring it down quickly.
Give glucagon if a diabetic person is unconscious and has signs of hypoglycemia.
Glucagon is for long-term glucose control, not emergencies.
questions.rationale: Glucagon is given in emergency situations for severe hypoglycemia when the patient is unconscious or unable to safely consume oral glucose. It stimulates the liver to release glucose, raising blood sugar. It’s not used for hyperglycemia (that would worsen things). In community or home settings, glucagon is given IM (or subQ); IV dextrose is used in hospital for severe cases. Glucagon is purely for short-term rescue, not long-term control.

questions.stem: One hour after receiving intravenous morphine sulfate, a patient reports generalized itching. The nurse assesses the patient and notes clear breath sounds, no rash, respirations of 14 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Prepare an epinephrine injection in case of an anaphylactic reaction.
Have resuscitation equipment available at the bedside.
Reassure the patient that this is a common side effect of this drug.
Administer naloxone to reverse an opiate overdose.
questions.rationale: Pruritus is a common opioid side effect and can be managed with diphenhydramine. Patients developing anaphylaxis will have urticaria and hypotension, and these patients will need epinephrine and resuscitation. Respiratory depression is a sign of morphine overdose, which will require naloxone.

questions.stem: A patient who is taking warfarin has an international normalized ratio (INR) of 5.5. The nurse will anticipate giving which of the following?
options: Fresh frozen plasma
Oral vitamin K
Intravenous iron
Protamine sulfate
questions.rationale: Vitamin K antagonizes the effects of warfarin, an oral anticoagulant. Patients with an INR of 5.5 should be given a low dose of oral vitamin K. Too much vitamin K may reduce the effectiveness of warfarin for up to 2 weeks. Fresh frozen plasma and intravenous iron are given for anemia caused by blood loss. Protamine sulfate is given for heparin overdose.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old patient who is overweight has had a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes for 2 years. The patient uses 20 units of long-acting insulin per day. The patient's fasting blood glucose (FBG) is 190 mg/dL. The patient asks the nurse about using an oral antidiabetic agent. The nurse understands that oral antidiabetic agents
options: May be used in patients with type 2 diabetes in combination with insulin.
May not be used since this patient's fasting blood glucose is too high.
Cannot be used if the patient is overweight.
Cannot be used once a patient requires insulin.
questions.rationale: Patients with type 2 diabetes often use long-acting insulin in combination with oral agents to manage blood glucose.

questions.stem: The nurse monitors a patient on theophylline (Theo-24). Which finding may indicate theophylline toxicity?
options: Urinary retention
Hypoglycemia
Tremors and palpitations
Constipation and dry mouth
questions.rationale: Signs of theophylline toxicity include CNS stimulation (tremors, seizures), and cardiovascular effects like palpitations or arrhythmias. GI upset (nausea/vomiting) is also common. Constipation and dry mouth are not hallmark toxicity signs (those are more anticholinergic side effects, not theophylline’s profile). Theophylline doesn’t cause hypoglycemia or urinary retention typically.

questions.stem: A patient will begin using ipratropium bromide, albuterol, and an inhaled corticosteroid medication to treat chronic bronchitis. When teaching this patient about disease and medication management, the nurse will instruct the patient to administer these medications in which order?
options: Ipratropium bromide, albuterol, inhaled corticosteroid
Albuterol, ipratropium bromide, inhaled corticosteroid
Albuterol, inhaled corticosteroid, ipratropium bromide
Inhaled corticosteroid, ipratropium bromide, albuterol
questions.rationale: Patients who use a beta agonist should be taught to use it 5 minutes before administering ipratropium bromide, and ipratropium bromide should be given 5 minutes prior to an inhaled glucocorticoid. This helps the bronchioles to dilate so the subsequent medication can be deposited in the bronchioles for improved effect.

questions.stem: Which instruction is most important for a patient taking amlodipine (Norvasc)?
options: Limit your potassium intake to prevent high levels.
Avoid drinking grapefruit juice while on this medication.
Increase your salt intake to counteract blood pressure drops.
Take this medication on an empty stomach in the morning.
questions.rationale: Grapefruit juice can increase serum levels of calcium channel blockers like amlodipine, risking toxicity or enhanced hypotensive effect. Patients should avoid it. Potassium levels are not directly affected by amlodipine (that warning is for ACE inhibitors/ARBs). It can be taken with or without food; there’s no strict timing like empty stomach required. Increasing salt is not advised in hypertension.

questions.stem: A patient will be discharged home with albuterol to use for asthma symptoms. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: Overuse of this medication can result in tolerance.
Failure to respond to the medication indicates a need for a higher dose.
Palpitations are common with this drug even at normal, therapeutic doses.
Monitor for hypoglycemia symptoms when using this medication.
questions.rationale: Excessive use of bronchodilators can result in tolerance to the medication. Hyperglycemia can occur. Palpitations are common with increased doses but not at therapeutic doses.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving diphenhydramine. The nurse notes that the patient has not voided for 12 hours. What action will the nurse take?
options: Request an order for urinary catheterization.
Encourage the patient to drink more fluids.
Request an order for an intravenous fluid bolus.
Evaluate the bladder to check for distension.
questions.rationale: Diphenhydramine has anticholinergic effects, including urinary retention. The nurse should assess for bladder distension to determine if this is the case. Encouraging the patient to drink more fluids or giving intravenous fluids may be necessary if the patient has oliguria secondary to dehydration. Urinary catheterization is not indicated until urinary retention has been diagnosed.

questions.stem: A patient who is taking aspirin for arthritis pain asks the nurse why it also causes gastrointestinal upset. The nurse understands that this is because aspirin
options: selectively inhibits COX-2.
increases gastrointestinal secretions.
increases hypersensitivity reactions.
inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2.
questions.rationale: Aspirin is a non-specific COX-1 and COX-2 inhibitor. COX-1 protects the stomach lining, so when it is inhibited, gastric upset can occur. Aspirin does not increase gastrointestinal secretions or hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.stem: When mixing insulin regular (Humulin R) and NPH (Humulin N) in the same syringe, what is the correct procedure?
options: Draw up the regular insulin first, then the NPH insulin.
These insulins cannot be mixed and must be given separately.
It doesn’t matter which insulin is drawn first.
Draw up the NPH insulin first, then the regular insulin.
questions.rationale: When mixing a short-acting insulin (regular) with NPH (intermediate-acting), you should draw up clear before cloudy – regular insulin (clear) first, then NPH (cloudy). This prevents contaminating the regular vial with NPH. Regular and NPH are compatible to mix in one syringe. So the nurse injects air into NPH vial, then air into regular vial, draws regular, then draws NPH.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer the first dose of hydrochlorothiazide 50 mg to a patient who has a blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg. The nurse notes that the patient had a urine output of 200 mL in the past 12 hours. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Administer the medication as ordered.
Hold the medication and request an order for serum BUN (blood urea nitrogen) and creatinine.
Request an order for serum electrolytes and administer the medication.
Encourage the patient to drink more fluids.
questions.rationale: Thiazide diuretics are contraindicated in renal failure. This patient has oliguria and should be evaluated for renal failure prior to administration of the diuretic, especially in the absence of known renal failure for this patient. Drinking more fluids will not increase urine output in patients with renal failure.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about sublingual nitroglycerin administration. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: Call 911 if pain does not improve after three doses.
Take the first tablet while sitting or lying down.
A second dose of nitroglycerin should be given regardless of symptom resolution.
Swallow the tablet with small sips of water.
questions.rationale: Because nitroglycerin can cause hypotension, patients should be cautioned to take it while sitting or lying down. If pain is not better or has worsened 5 minutes after the first dose, patients should call 911. A second dose should be administered only if symptoms are not resolved after taking the first dose. The tablets must dissolve under the tongue and should not be swallowed.

questions.stem: Which organ’s function is a priority to monitor periodically in a patient on long-term amiodarone (Cordarone)?
options: Urinary bladder
Lungs
Bone marrow
Pancreas
questions.rationale: Amiodarone has multiple potential toxicities, but the most severe is pulmonary fibrosis (lung toxicity). Pulmonary function or symptoms should be monitored closely. Thyroid and liver function are also often monitored with amiodarone, but among the options given, the lungs are the priority. It does not primarily affect the pancreas, bone marrow, or bladder.

questions.stem: A patient is receiving antitubercular treatment for latent TB. The patient develops symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and is started on pyridoxine (vitamin B ). The nurse suspects this was caused by which of the following medications?
options: Kanamycin
Isoniazid
Ethambutol
Rifampin
questions.rationale: Peripheral neuropathy can be a problem in patients taking isoniazid, especially for those who are malnourished, have diabetes mellitus, or are alcoholics. This condition can be prevented if pyridoxine (vitamin B ) is administered.

questions.stem: A patient has recently begun taking phenytoin (Dilantin) for a seizure disorder. The nurse notes a reddish-brown color to the patient’s urine. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Ask the provider to order a serum drug level.
Request an order for a urinalysis and creatinine clearance.
Reassure the patient that this is a harmless side effect.
Report possible thrombocytopenia to the provider.
questions.rationale: Reddish-brown urine is a harmless side effect of phenytoin. The nurse should reassure the patient. It is not necessary to order a serum drug level or renal function studies. It is not a symptom of thrombocytopenia.

questions.stem: Which of the following is FALSE regarding pyridostigmine?
options: It is poorly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract.
Atropine is the antidote for pyridostigmine overdose.
Pyridostigmine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist.
Overdosing on pyridostigmine can result in a cholinergic crisis.
questions.rationale: Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and does not antagonize muscarinic receptors. The drug is poorly absorbed from the GI tract. Overdosing with pyridostigmine results in a cholinergic crisis, and atropine is used as an antidote for pyridostigmine overdose.

questions.stem: The nurse provides teaching for a patient who will begin taking phenytoin. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “Most people develop diabetes while taking this medication.”
“I should not be alarmed if my urine turns reddish-brown.”
“If I experience bleeding gums, I should stop taking the medication immediately.”
“If I develop a rash, I should take diphenhydramine to control the itching.”
questions.rationale: Phenytoin can cause reddish-brown colored urine. Patients should be counseled to report a rash to the provider because it could be a serious adverse reaction. Bleeding gums are common, but patients should never stop taking anticonvulsants abruptly, or they may develop seizures. Changes in blood glucose may occur, but do not necessarily result in diabetes.

questions.stem: A client is admitted to the hospital for diagnostic testing for possible myasthenia gravis. The nurse prepares for intravenous administration of edrophonium chloride (Tensilon). What is the expected outcome for this client following administration of this pharmacologic agent?
options: Progressive difficulty with swallowing.
Decreased respiratory effort.
Improvement in generalized fatigue.
Decreased muscle weakness.

questions.stem: A patient on warfarin (Coumadin) therapy has an INR of 4.6. They deny bleeding symptoms. What action should the nurse anticipate?
options: Administering vitamin K because the INR is critically high
Holding the next dose of warfarin and notifying the provider for potential dose adjustment
Increasing the warfarin dose to reach the target INR
Advising the patient to eat more salads to bring down the INR
questions.rationale: An INR of 4.6 is above the typical therapeutic range (usually 2.0–3.0 for most indications). Without bleeding, the usual step is to hold or reduce the dose and let the INR come down, per provider’s order. Vitamin K is the antidote for warfarin and is given for very high INRs or if bleeding occurs; 4.6 in an asymptomatic patient might not require immediate vitamin K, just dose adjustment. Increasing the dose is wrong as INR is already high. Eating vitamin K-rich foods (like salads) can lower INR, but patients are generally taught to keep intake consistent; one doesn’t “chase” a high INR with diet acutely – medication adjustment is the primary approach.

questions.stem: A peak and trough level must be drawn for a client receiving antibiotic therapy. What is the optimum time for the nurse to obtain the trough level?
options: Sixty minutes after the antibiotic dose is administered.
Immediately before the next antibiotic dose is given.
When the next blood glucose level is to be checked.
Thirty minutes before the next antibiotic dose is given.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will begin taking furosemide. The nurse learns that the patient has just begun a 2-week course of a steroid medication. What will the nurse recommend?
options: Consume licorice to prevent excess potassium loss.
Obtain an order for a potassium supplement.
Report a urine output greater than 600 mL/24 hours.
Take the furosemide at bedtime.
questions.rationale: The interaction of furosemide and a steroid drug can result in an increased loss of potassium. Patients should take a potassium supplement. Patients should avoid licorice while taking furosemide, partially due to the hypokalemic effects of both substances. Urine output greater than 600 mL/24 hours is normal. Patients should take furosemide in the morning to avoid nocturia.

questions.stem: A patient who has type 2 diabetes mellitus asks the nurse why the provider has changed their oral antidiabetic agent from tolbutamide (Orinase) to glipizide (Glucotrol). The nurse will explain that glipizide
options: Has fewer gastrointestinal side effects.
May be taken on an as-needed basis.
Has a longer duration of action.
Does not cause hypoglycemia.
questions.rationale: Glipizide is a second-generation sulfonylurea. It has a longer duration of action than the first-generation sulfonylurea, tolbutamide. It has many gastrointestinal side effects. It is taken once daily, not as needed. All sulfonylureas can contribute to hypoglycemia.

questions.stem: A female client with RA takes ibuprofen (Motrin) 600mg PO 4xday. To prevent GI bleeding, misoprostol (cytotec) 100mcg PO is prescribed. Which information is most important for the nurse to include in client teaching?
options: Use contraception during intercourse
Ensure the Cytotec is taken on an empty stomach
Encourage oral fluid intake to prevent constipation
Take Cytotec 30 minutes prior to Motrin

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an older patient who is taking 25 mg per day of hydrochlorothiazide. The nurse will closely monitor which lab value in this patient?
options: Coagulation studies
Serum potassium
LFTs
White blood count
questions.rationale: Older patients who take doses of hydrochlorothiazide between 25 and 50 mg/day have an increased risk of electrolyte imbalances, so potassium should be monitored.

questions.stem: A category X drug is prescribed for a young adult female client. Which instruction is most important for the nurse to teach this client?
options: Use a reliable form of birth control.
Avoid exposure to ultraviolet light.
Refuse this medication if planning pregnancy.
Abstain from intercourse while on this drug.

questions.stem: A patient with chronic stable angina uses sublingual nitroglycerin (Nitrostat) for chest pain. Which statement by the patient indicates correct understanding of how to use this medication?
options: If I get a headache after taking nitroglycerin, I should go to the ER immediately.
I should swallow the tablet with water for fastest absorption.
I will sit or lie down before taking a nitroglycerin tablet for chest pain.
I can take up to five nitroglycerin tablets, 5 minutes apart, if chest pain persists.
questions.rationale: The patient should sit or lie down when taking nitroglycerin due to risk of dizziness or hypotension from the vasodilation. For ongoing chest pain, the recommendation is up to 3 sublingual tablets, 5 minutes apart, and call emergency services if pain persists after one tablet (per guidelines). Headache is a common side effect of nitroglycerin (due to vasodilation) and can be treated with analgesics; it’s not usually an emergency. Sublingual nitro should not be swallowed; it must dissolve under the tongue for quick absorption.

questions.stem: A patient with hypertension and heart failure is prescribed spironolactone (Aldactone). Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further education?
options: I’ll continue to take my daily potassium supplement with this diuretic.
I will avoid salt substitutes while taking this medication.
I need to watch for high potassium levels because of this drug.
This medication will help prevent low potassium when used with my other diuretic.
questions.rationale: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic. Patients should not take extra potassium or potassium-based salt substitutes, as this can lead to dangerous hyperkalemia. Options a, b, and d are correct: avoiding salt substitutes (which often contain potassium) is appropriate, monitoring for hyperkalemia is necessary, and spironolactone is often used with loop/thiazide diuretics to counteract potassium loss.

questions.stem: A patient with hyperthyroidism is started on propylthiouracil (PTU). What is the most serious side effect the nurse will educate the patient about?
options: Hair loss
Weight gain
Sore throat or fever (agranulocytosis)
Tinnitus
questions.rationale: Propylthiouracil (and similar thionamides like methimazole) can cause agranulocytosis – a dangerous drop in WBCs. Early signs include sore throat, fever, or other infection signs. Patients must report those immediately. Hair loss can occur initially but is not the most dangerous. Weight gain may occur as thyroid levels normalize (from hyper- to euthyroid), but it’s expected and not dangerous. Tinnitus is not associated with PTU.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer the anticholinergic medication benztropine (Cogentin) to a patient who has Parkinson's disease. The nurse understands that this drug is used primarily for which purpose?
options: To prevent urinary retention
To suppress tremors and lessen muscle rigidity
To improve mobility and muscle strength
To decrease drooling and excessive salivation
questions.rationale: Anticholinergic drugs are used in Parkinson's disease mainly to reduce tremors and muscle rigidity.

questions.stem: The nurse is performing a medication history on a patient who reports long-term use of montelukast and an albuterol metered-dose inhaler. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss an order for which laboratory tests?
options: Cardiac enzymes and serum calcium
Liver function tests and serum glucose
Electrolytes and a complete blood count
Urinalysis and serum magnesium
questions.rationale: The beta agonists can increase serum glucose levels, and montelukast can elevate liver enzymes, so these should be monitored in patients taking these medications.

questions.stem: What important instruction should the nurse give a female patient of childbearing age who is starting propylthiouracil (PTU) for hyperthyroidism?
options: Notify your provider immediately if you suspect you are pregnant, as PTU is generally preferred in the first trimester.
Increase your iodine intake while on PTU to help it work.
This medication will make your birth control pills more effective.
Do not take this drug if you plan to become pregnant; it’s completely contraindicated.
questions.rationale: PTU is actually the preferred antithyroid medication during the first trimester of pregnancy (because methimazole has teratogenic effects in the first trimester). After the first trimester, patients are usually switched to methimazole due to PTU’s liver toxicity risk. So if the patient becomes pregnant, the provider needs to know to manage therapy appropriately. PTU doesn’t increase birth control effectiveness (no such interaction). It’s not absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy (methimazole is more so in first trimester). Increasing iodine intake (unless directed for specific therapy) is not advised; excess iodine can actually affect thyroid function unpredictably.

questions.stem: A patient who takes high-dose aspirin to treat arthritis will need to take prednisone to treat an acute flare of symptoms. What action will the nurse perform?
options: Monitor closely for increased urine output.
Request an order for enteric-coated aspirin.
Observe the patient for hypoglycemia.
Observe the patient for hypotension.
questions.rationale: Glucocorticoids can increase gastric distress, so an enteric-coated aspirin product is indicated. Glucocorticoids increase the risk of hypoglycemia, fluid retention, and hypertension.

questions.stem: A medication that is classified as a beta-1 agonist is most commonly prescribed for a client with which condition?
options: Glaucoma.
Hypertension.
Heart failure.
Asthma.

questions.stem: A client has a continuous IV infusion of dopamine and an IV of normal saline at 50ml/hour. The nurse notes that the client's urinary output has been 20ml/hour for the last two hours. Which intervention should the nurse initiate?
options: Stop the infusion of dopamine
Change the normal saline to a keep-open rate
Replace the urinary catheter
Notify the healthcare provider of the urinary output.

questions.stem: A patient on inhaled fluticasone (Flovent) reports white patches in the mouth and tongue. What is the likely cause and appropriate action?
options: A normal coating from the inhaler propellant; no action needed.
Oral leukoplakia; advise the patient to stop the inhaler immediately.
Oral thrush from the steroid; instruct the patient to rinse the mouth and notify the provider for antifungal treatment.
A reaction to lactose in the inhaler; have the patient take diphenhydramine.
questions.rationale: White patches in the mouth for a patient on inhaled corticosteroids likely indicate oral candidiasis (thrush). This occurs if the patient doesn’t rinse after use. The nurse should reinforce rinsing and notify the provider; an antifungal mouth rinse or treatment may be needed. It’s not due to lactose or propellant, and it’s not leukoplakia (which is a precancerous lesion unrelated to inhaler use). The patient shouldn’t stop the steroid without provider advice, but they do need treatment for thrush.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about the use of a transdermal nitroglycerin patch. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I will remove the old patch and replace it with a new one at bedtime each day.”
“I should rotate sites when changing the patch to prevent skin irritation.”
“I will apply the patch as needed when I experience anginal pain.”
“When I am symptom-free, I may stop using the patch on a regular basis.”
questions.rationale: Patients should be taught to rotate application sites when using the transdermal nitroglycerin. Transdermal nitroglycerin is not used as needed. Patients should remove the patch at bedtime to provide an 8- to 12-hour nitrate-free interval. Patients should use the patch even when symptom-free unless otherwise instructed by the provider.

questions.stem: A patient on Ortho Tri-Cyclen birth control pills missed two consecutive doses. What should the nurse instruct her to do?
options: Follow the package instructions: you may need to take two pills for the next two days and use backup contraception.
Double the dose today and no backup method is necessary.
Stop the pack and discard it, then start a new pack immediately.
It’s fine, just continue one pill daily; the effectiveness isn’t affected until three or more pills are missed.
questions.rationale: If two active pills are missed, most oral contraceptive guidelines suggest taking two pills as soon as remembered (or two pills per day for two days) and using backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for at least 7 days because effectiveness is reduced. The exact instructions can vary slightly by brand, but generally doubling up and backup is needed. Stopping the pack is usually advised if more than two are missed or if certain weeks are missed, but not for just two. Effectiveness is affected by missing two pills, so backup is needed. Simply doubling once is not enough without backup. Always check the specific pill’s instructions, but option a captures the typical approach.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient in the post-anesthesia recovery unit. The nurse notes that the patient received atropine sulfate 2 mg 30 minutes prior to anesthesia induction. The patient has received 1000 mL of intravenous fluids and has 700 mL of urine in the urinary catheter bag. The patient reports having a dry mouth. The nurse notes a heart rate of 82 beats per minute. What action will the nurse perform?
options: Reassess the patient in 15 minutes.
Administer a fluid bolus.
Palpate the patient’s bladder.
Give the patient ice chips.
questions.rationale: Atropine can cause urinary retention. The patient’s urine output is less than the fluid intake, so the nurse should palpate the bladder to assess for distension. Dry mouth is an expected side effect and does not necessarily indicate dehydration in a patient who has been administered atropine.

questions.stem: Succinylcholine (Anectine) is used during rapid sequence intubation for anesthesia. Shortly after administration, the patient’s jaw and body become rigid, and their temperature rises rapidly. What medication should the nurse prepare to administer?
options: Epinephrine IV
Neostigmine IV
Dantrolene (Dantrium) IV
Naloxone (Narcan) IV
questions.rationale: The scenario describes signs of malignant hyperthermia (muscle rigidity, sudden fever) triggered by succinylcholine (and possibly inhaled anesthetics). The treatment is IV dantrolene, a muscle relaxant that specifically treats malignant hyperthermia by reducing calcium release in muscles. Naloxone reverses opioids (not relevant here). Neostigmine reverses non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (not succinylcholine, a depolarizing type). Epinephrine is for anaphylaxis or cardiac arrest, not for malignant hyperthermia.

questions.stem: A woman is diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and will begin taking metronidazole (Flagyl). What will the nurse teach the patient about this medication?
options: “Do not consume alcohol while taking this drug and for 48 hours after finishing the prescription.”
“Abstain from sexual intercourse while taking this medication.”
“Take this medication on an empty stomach to increase absorption.”
“Topical preparations are ineffective for treating bacterial vaginosis.”
questions.rationale: Metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol, so patients should be cautioned against using foods or drug products that contain alcohol. There is no need to abstain from sexual intercourse. Metronidazole should be taken with food. The topical preparation is effective against bacterial vaginosis.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient after the third stage of labor, and the provider orders 20 units of oxytocin to be added to 1,000 mL of IV solution to be infused. The nurse will explain to the patient that this drug is being used for which purpose?
options: To suppress lactation
To prevent uterine atony
To enhance milk letdown
To allow the cervix to close
questions.rationale: After delivery of the infant, oxytocin is given to help the uterus stay contracted and prevent uterine atony. It does not constrict the cervix. Intranasal oxytocin may be given later to enhance letdown of breast milk. Oxytocin does not suppress lactation.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about using high-dose aspirin to treat arthritis. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: “You will need to monitor aspirin levels if you are also taking warfarin.”
“A normal serum aspirin level is between 30 and 40 mg/dL.”
“Your stools may become dark, but this is a harmless side effect.”
“You may need to stop taking this drug a week prior to surgery.”
questions.rationale: Aspirin should be discontinued prior to surgery to avoid prolonged bleeding time. A normal serum level is 15 to 30 mg/dL. Patients taking warfarin and aspirin will require INR monitoring. Tarry stools are a symptom of gastrointestinal bleeding and should be reported.

questions.stem: A patient is taking aspirin for secondary prevention of myocardial infarction and is experiencing moderate gastrointestinal upset. The nurse will contact the patient's provider to discuss changing from aspirin to which of the following?
options: Enteric-coated aspirin
Ibuprofen
Celecoxib
A COX-2 inhibitor
questions.rationale: Aspirin is often used to inhibit platelet aggregation for cardiovascular prevention. Patients taking aspirin for this purpose would not benefit from COX-2 inhibitors, since the COX-1 enzyme is responsible for inhibiting platelet aggregation. The patient may benefit from taking an enteric-coated aspirin product to lessen the gastrointestinal distress. Celecoxib is a COX-2 selective inhibitor. Ibuprofen is not indicated for cardiovascular event prevention.

questions.stem: A patient with heart failure is being treated with furosemide (Lasix). Which assessment finding indicates the patient may be experiencing an adverse effect of this medication?
options: Blood pressure increase from 130/80 to 150/90 mmHg
An apical pulse of 110 beats per minute
Generalized muscle weakness and leg cramps
Weight gain of 2 kg in 2 days
questions.rationale: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes loss of potassium, which can lead to hypokalemia. Muscle weakness and leg cramps are signs of low potassium. An increase in BP or weight gain would suggest the drug isn’t effective enough (not an adverse effect, but a lack of effect). Tachycardia could occur if the patient is volume-depleted, but the muscle symptoms are more directly indicative of a diuretic adverse effect (electrolyte imbalance).

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a diabetic patient about metoprolol (Lopressor) therapy for hypertension. Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: I will check my blood sugar often because this drug can mask a low blood sugar.
If I feel dizzy, I’ll stop taking the medication immediately.
This drug may hide the shakiness I feel when my sugar is low.
I should not abruptly stop taking this medication.
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers can mask signs of hypoglycemia (like tachycardia and tremors), so diabetics should monitor glucose closely. They also must not be stopped abruptly, as rebound hypertension or angina can occur. Feeling dizzy (a sign of lowered blood pressure) should be reported, but the patient should not discontinue the drug without consulting the provider. Option d reflects incorrect self-management.

questions.stem: Trough levels are drawn when the blood level is at its lowest, which is typically just before the next dose is given (B). (A, C, and D) Do not describe the optimum time for obtaining a trough level of an antibiotic. Which antidiarrheal agent should be used with caution in clients taking high dosages of aspirin for arthritis?
options: Loperamide (Imodium).
Probanthine (Propantheline).
Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto Bismol).
Diphenoxylate hydrochloride with atropine (Lomotil).

questions.stem: A patient with diabetes insipidus is receiving desmopressin (DDAVP) nasal spray. Which outcome indicates the medication is having the desired effect?
options: Decreased urine output and increased urine specific gravity
Lower blood glucose levels
Increased thirst and fluid intake
Reduced blood pressure
questions.rationale: Diabetes insipidus causes large volumes of dilute urine due to ADH deficiency. Desmopressin is an ADH analog. Its effectiveness is shown by the urine output decreasing to normal and urine becoming more concentrated (higher specific gravity). Thirst should decrease as fluid balance is restored, not increase. It does not directly affect blood glucose. It may raise blood pressure if it was low (from dehydration), but the primary measure is urine output normalization.

questions.stem: A patient has been taking warfarin (Coumadin), which is highly protein-bound. The patient will begin taking gemfibrozil, which is also highly protein-bound. The nurse will observe the patient closely for
options: decreased effects of warfarin.
increased effects of warfarin.
decreased effects of gemfibrozil.
decreased the effects of both drugs.
questions.rationale: Addition of a highly protein-bound drug will compete with warfarin for protein-binding sites, releasing more free warfarin into the system, increasing drug effects, and increasing the chance of toxicity (bleeding).

questions.stem: A patient reports that they are taking a rapid-acting insulin with meals, but can't remember the name. Which of the following products is a rapid-acting insulin?
options: Insulin lispro (Humalog)
Insulin degludec (Tresiba)
Regular insulin (Novolin R)
Insulin glargine (Lantus)
questions.rationale: Insulin lispro (Humalog) is a rapid-acting insulin product. Regular insulin is considered a short-acting insulin. Insulin glargine and insulin degludec are long-acting insulins.

questions.stem: A patient is scheduled for a CT scan with IV contrast tomorrow. The patient takes metformin (Glucophage) for type 2 diabetes. What should the nurse do?
options: Hold the metformin on the day of the test and for 48 hours after contrast administration.
Increase hydration and continue metformin as usual.
Switch the patient to insulin for 24 hours before and after the scan.
Double the metformin dose the day before to protect the kidneys.
questions.rationale: IV contrast dye can impair kidney function, and metformin in the setting of acute kidney injury can accumulate and cause lactic acidosis. Standard practice is to hold metformin on the day of the procedure and for 48 hours after, until renal function is confirmed to be normal. Hydration is important but not the only step. Doubling the dose is wrong. Temporarily using insulin might be necessary if glucose control is an issue, but the key point is holding metformin – not all patients automatically require insulin.

questions.stem: The nurse is transcribing a new prescription for spironolactone (aldactone) for a client who receives an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Which action should the nurse implement
options: Verify both prescriptions with the HCP
Report the med interactions to the nurse manager
Hold the ACE inhibitor and give the new prescription
Transcribe and send the prescription to the pharmacy

questions.stem: A cancer patient is taking oxycodone extended-release (OxyContin) 40 mg every 12 hours for chronic pain. What instruction is critical for the safe use of this medication?
options: Take this medication whenever pain is above a 5 out of 10.
Stop this medication if you experience any drowsiness.
Swallow the tablet whole; do not crush, chew, or break it.
Avoid taking any immediate-release pain medication with this drug.
questions.rationale: Extended-release oxycodone (OxyContin) must be swallowed whole; crushing or chewing can release a potentially fatal dose at once. It’s taken on a scheduled basis (every 12 hours), not prn based on pain rating (immediate-release versions are used prn for breakthrough). Patients can still take prescribed breakthrough immediate-release opioids along with ER as directed. Drowsiness is an expected side effect initially; they shouldn’t stop the med but rather consult their provider if side effects are concerning. The critical safety point is not to tamper with the ER tablet.

questions.stem: A patient is prescribed raloxifene as a cancer prophylactic agent. Which type of cancer is this being used to prevent?
options: Prostate cancer
Breast cancer
Multiple myeloma
Colon cancer
questions.rationale: Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen and raloxifene have both estrogenic and antiestrogenic effects on various tissues. Tamoxifen is primarily used for breast cancer in both men and women. Raloxifene produces estrogenic effects in bone and lipids and has an antiestrogenic property in mammary tissues. It is used as a prophylactic against breast cancer in high-risk postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

questions.stem: A patient is taking phenytoin to prevent seizures. The nurse knows that phenytoin is highly protein-bound and has sedating effects. The nurse reviews the patient's chart and notes a low serum albumin. The nurse will notify the provider and observe the patient for which effects?
options: Increased seizures
No change in effects
Decreased sedative effects
Increased sedative effects
questions.rationale: Phenytoin is highly protein-bound. When patients have a low serum albumin, there are fewer protein-binding sites, resulting in more free drug in the system. The nurse should expect the potential for an increase in the sedative side effects of phenytoin.

questions.stem: A patient is brought to the emergency department after exposure to organophosphate pesticides while at work. The nurse will expect to administer which medication to reverse the toxic effects of this substance?
options: Flumazenil
Epinephrine
Atropine sulfate
Diazepam
questions.rationale: Atropine is used to counter the toxic effects of organophosphate pesticides. Diazepam is given for seizures and for acute alcohol withdrawal. Epinephrine is used for anaphylaxis. Flumazenil is given as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

questions.stem: The nurse has just administered Rho(D) immune globulin to a postpartum woman. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: “The immune globulin does not cross into breast milk.”
“Avoid live vaccines for 3 months.”
“You will not need to have the injection with future deliveries.”
“There are no adverse reactions to this injection.”
questions.rationale: Patients receiving Rh (D) immune globulin should be cautioned to avoid live vaccines for 3 months. Patients can experience hypersensitivity reactions to the immune globulin, and Rh (D) immune globulin crosses into breast milk. Women will need to have the immunoglobulin with future deliveries if the infant is Rh-positive.

questions.stem: A patient on clopidogrel (Plavix) should be instructed to avoid which over-the-counter medication due to additive bleeding risk?
options: Calcium carbonate (antacid)
Guaifenesin (cough syrup)
Naproxen (NSAID)
Loratadine (antihistamine)
questions.rationale: NSAIDs (like naproxen, ibuprofen) can potentiate bleeding risk when taken with antiplatelet agents like clopidogrel, because NSAIDs also affect platelet function and can cause GI irritation/bleeding. Patients on clopidogrel are usually advised to avoid NSAIDs unless absolutely necessary. Guaifenesin, loratadine, and antacids do not have significant bleeding interactions with clopidogrel.

questions.stem: A patient with asthma is prescribed albuterol (Ventolin) inhaler and fluticasone (Flovent) inhaler. What instructions should the nurse provide about using these inhalers?
options: Save the albuterol for severe attacks only and use fluticasone daily before exercise.
It doesn’t matter which inhaler you use first, as long as you use both.
Use the albuterol inhaler first for quick relief, then use the fluticasone inhaler.
Take the fluticasone first, then the albuterol 5 minutes later.
questions.rationale: Albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator (rescue inhaler) and should be used first to open the airways, then after a few minutes the corticosteroid (fluticasone) can be inhaled so it penetrates deeper into the lungs. Fluticasone is a maintenance inhaler, not for immediate relief or before exercise (that role is for short-acting bronchodilators). The sequence matters: bronchodilator before steroid.

questions.stem: The nitrate isosorbide dinitrate (Isordil) is prescribed for a client with angina. Which instruction should the nurse include in this client's discharge teaching plan?
options: Quit taking the medication if dizziness occurs.
Do not get up quickly. Always rise slowly.
Take the medication with food only.
Increase your intake of potassium-rich foods.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a dose of lithium to a patient who has been taking the drug as maintenance therapy to treat bipolar disorder. The nurse assesses the patient and notes tremors and confusion. The patient's latest serum lithium level was two mEq/L. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Request an order for a lower dose.
Hold the dose and notify the provider.
Administer the dose.
Request an order for a higher dose.
questions.rationale: The patient has symptoms of lithium toxicity, and the serum drug level is in the toxic range. The nurse should hold the dose and notify the provider.

questions.stem: The parent of a child who is receiving chemotherapy asks the nurse why metoclopramide is not being used to suppress vomiting. The nurse will explain that, in children, this drug is more likely to cause which adverse effect?
options: Extrapyramidal symptoms
Paralytic ileus
Excess sedation
Vertigo
questions.rationale: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal symptoms, and these effects are more likely in children. Children are not more prone to sedative effects, paralytic ileus, or vertigo while taking this drug.

questions.stem: During resuscitation of a 5-year-old child, the provider requests a dose of 1 mL of epinephrine to be given STAT. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Draw up the dose and give it as a rapid intravenous bolus.
Give the dose as a slow intravenous bolus and monitor vital signs.
Ask the provider to clarify the dose, route, and concentration.
Request an order to give the dose via endotracheal tube.
questions.rationale: Epinephrine is available in two primary concentrations: 1:1,000 and 1:10,000 mL. The 1:10,000 concentration is used when giving a single IV dose of epinephrine. The 1:1,000 concentration is used for other routes. The nurse should clarify the dose, route, and concentration prior to administration.

questions.stem: A client has myxedema, which results from a deficiency of thyroid hormone synthesis in adults. The nurse knows which medication should be contraindicated for this client?
options: liothyronine (cytomel) to replace iodine
Furosemide (Lasix) for relief of fluid retention
Pentobarbital sodium for sleep
nitroglycerin for angina pain

questions.stem: A patient with type 1 diabetes is ordered insulin lispro (Humalog) 10 units at breakfast. When should the nurse administer this insulin?
options: Within 15 minutes before the patient begins eating breakfast
One hour before the meal
Immediately after the meal
At bedtime the night before
questions.rationale: Insulin lispro is a rapid-acting insulin. It should be given about 15 minutes before a meal (or even as the patient starts eating) because it has a quick onset (~15 minutes). Giving it an hour before would risk hypoglycemia before the meal. Giving it after the meal could cause post-meal hyperglycemia (ideally it’s pre-meal, though some may give immediately after if intake is uncertain). It is never given the night before for a breakfast dose, as its action is too short.

questions.stem: A patient is being treated with isoniazid (INH), rifampin, and pyrazinamide in the initial phase of treatment for tuberculosis. The organism develops resistance to isoniazid. Which drug will the nurse anticipate the provider will order to replace the isoniazid?
options: Ciprofloxacin
Ethambutol
Streptomycin sulfate
Kanamycin
questions.rationale: If there is bacterial resistance to isoniazid, the first phase may be changed to ethambutol, rifampin, and pyrazinamide. Ciprofloxacin, kanamycin, and streptomycin are not generally first-line antitubercular drugs.
